history.content: my personal opinion: 16A, 61A, 61B, 70 in terms of conceptual difficulty, though people more mathematically inclined may find 70 not that bad (maybe on the order of 61B).  In terms of time commitment, 61B took up more of my time than 70.  61A is often hard for incoming students, myself included, but looking back, it pales in difficulty compared to 61B (but luckily your skills will have improved vastly to make 61B fun and hopefully possible).

my personal opinion: 16A, 61A, 61B, 70 in terms of conceptual difficulty, though people more mathematically inclined may find 70 not that bad.  In terms of time commitment, 61B took up more of my time than 70.

children.subject:
I think it really depends on how much CS knowledge you had prior to the classes. For me, I came in knowing how to code, so in order of least to most difficult it was 61A, 61B, EE16A, CS70. 61A I found to have a lot of small tricky things, but 61B was more time consuming and conceptually challenging. EE16A isn't too bad if you've taken Math 54 (which is what I did), but it is fairly fast paced in some sections. CS70 in my opinion was vastly harder than any of the other classes, in that problem sets took up a large amount of time each week, and the exams were both tricky conceptually hard.

I did also take 61A/61B with Denero and Hug respectively though, and from what I've heard they give less of a hard time than Hilfinger :')

61A < 16A < 61B < 70.

Disclaimer: not a fan of math

Do not take 70 without taking 16A. It will be hell. It's not even that the material is related at all (it isn't), it's about mathematical maturity. If you blew through 54 or something, sure take 70, but 16A then 70 is a far worthier investment of time, gradewise, learningwise, workloadwise, whatever. 

16A and 70 also kind of suck your soul with homework. Would not take them with more than one other tech or in semesters with > 15 units, especially during your Freshman/Sophomore years

61A < 61B < 16A < 70

This is with Hilfinger too, just not a mathy type person and hated the long boring homeworks from 16A and 70, whereas 61 series felt like we were making something cool.
16A < 61B < 61A < 70 - came in with no coding experience
It 100% depends on mathmatical maturity, and what kind of student you are. For me, it was 70 < 16A < 61A < 61B. But I've never seen some one with a similar ordering.

history.content: How would y'all rank these in order of difficulty? Thanks!
history.subject: CS61A, CS61B, CS70, EE16A
